Derek James wrote:

>On Thu, 05 Aug 2004 00:14:01 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>I don't quite follow how this exponential increase in complexity comes
>>about. I suppose it depends on how you set up the roving eye, I was
>>thinking that the network would have something like two (x and y)
>>outputs for the coordinates the eye should be looking at, the experiment
>>code then supplies the appropriate image to the eye's sensor inputs.
>>    
>>
>
>That's where the complexity comes in, with the size of the eye. 
>[...]
>
>If you scale up the size of the sensor area for the eye, you are
>exponentially increasing the size of the network needed.  A 3x3 eye
>needs 9 sensor nodes, but a 5x5 needs 25, and so on.
>  
>
Ahh yes of course...

>It almost sounds as if you were assuming that the eye would only be
>looking at a single pixel, or only receiving one sensory input value,
>each time step.
>  
>
No I just wasn't thinking straight.

There is a pay off here, smaller eyes require less complexity but then 
you are putting more faith in the ability to recognise a character (or 
geometric shape, etc) by roving.  In fact this is a fundamentally 
different technique to the frame and recognise technique I described in 
the last email. I understand though that the roving eye technique is 
more scalable, so I think it would be interesting to compare the two 
techniques on a range of different tasks.

Colin.
